User moved to section "Step 3".
why does the chicken have to rest in the zip lock back before its mixed in the flour mixture

That's a really great question! You should place the chicken in a zip lock bag in order to brine it. An overnight brine will penetrate a few millimeters into the meat, giving you built-in seasoning before you ever get to the breading.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.section_title: Inside Out
provenance.paragraph_text: An overnight brine will penetrate a few millimeters into the meat, giving you built-in seasoning before you ever get to the breading.

conversation.utterance: does it matter if it sits for longer then the 24 hours?

Usually, you should be brining your chicken breast anywhere from 30 minutes to two hours. However, a much, much longer brining time mitigates the effects of high-temperature frying, delivering a uniquely smooth, juicy texture to the meat.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.section_title: Inside Out
provenance.paragraph_text: My normal brining for chicken breast is anywhere from 30 minutes to two hours.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.section_title: Inside Out
provenance.paragraph_text: In this case, however, a much, much longer brining time was necessary in order to completely mitigate the effects of high-temperature frying, delivering a uniquely smooth, juicy texture to the meat.

User moved to section "Step 4".
how do i maintain the correct temperature of the oil

We know that shimmering oil is hotter than pooled oil (it starts shimmering at around 300 to 400°F), while smoking oil is hotter still (depending on the type of oil, this begins at around 450 to 500°F). In other words, oil is a built-in temperature indicator so simply looking at it should be enough

provenance.page_title: Do I Need To Preheat My Oil? | Ask The Food Lab
provenance.section_title: Do I Need To Preheat My Oil?
provenance.paragraph_text: You may be asking why you can't preheat the pan, then add the oil, and the answer is that you can, technically. The problem is that without oil in it, it's very difficult to determine how hot a pan actually is. Starting with oil in the pan is a good indicator of how hot the pan is. We know that shimmering oil is hotter than pooled oil (it starts shimmering at around 300 to 400°F), while smoking oil is hotter still (depending on the type of oil, this begins at around 450 to 500°F). The oil is a built-in temperature indicator.

conversation.utterance: what do I do if the chicken is sticking to the pan once in the oil

To avoid that you should adjust the heat to maintain the temperature at 300°F for the duration of the cooking. Then fry the chicken until it’s a deep golden brown on the first side, about 6 minutes; do not move the chicken or start checking for doneness until it has fried for at least 3 minutes, or you may knock off the coating.  Then, carefully flip the chicken pieces with tongs and cook until the second side is golden brown, about 4 minutes longer.

conversation.utterance: should I use a lid?
You can use a lid over the pan to cook through. Any lid will do (sauce pan, baking dish etc.) as long as it mostly covers the food being cooked, without touching it, and is heatproof.

provenance.page_title: Should I press the chicken breast against the pan when I grill it?
provenance.section_title: Answer 3
provenance.paragraph_text:
A technique to try if you don't have an oven:

Lightly oil the pan and the surface of the chicken just before frying (nothing is gained in doing it earlier)

You do not need to pound and otherwise manipulate the chicken

Fry the chicken briefly in the pan to colour the outside, then lower the temperature and place a lid over the pan to cook through (to simulate a small oven). Any lid will do (sauce pan, baking dish etc.) as long as it mostly covers the food being cooked, without touching it, and is heat proof. A folded up piece of aluminium foil will do at a pinch, but better to invest in something reusable

Cook for the time required (as if in a normal oven), and when nearly done, increase heat and remove the lid to fry off condensation, and crisp the outside as desired

Around 20 minutes cooking is the normal time with the lid on. If the chicken is burning before this time, you have the pan on too hot. Adjust time for thickness of chicken

This technique can even be used for a whole chicken (spatchcocked)

User moved to section "Step 6".
will all the pieces be done at the same time?

No, you should bake until thickest part of breast pieces registers 150°F (65.5°C) on an instant-read thermometer, and thigh/drumstick pieces register 165°F (74°C), 5 to 10 minutes

Then remove chicken pieces as they reach their target temperature.

provenance.page_title: The Best Buttermilk-Brined Southern Fried Chicken Recipe
provenance.section_title: The Best Buttermilk-Brined Southern Fried Chicken Recipe
provenance.paragraph_text: Bake until thickest part of breast pieces registers 150°F (65.5°C) on an instant-read thermometer, and thigh/drumstick pieces register 165°F (74°C), 5 to 10 minutes; remove chicken pieces as they reach their target temperature, and transfer to a second wire rack set in a rimmed baking sheet, or a paper towel-lined plate.

User moved to section "Step 7".
Is the total fry time about 5 minutes

No. Once you have gone through the previous steps you can simply serve the chicken. However, if you placed the chicken in the refrigerator for at least 1 hour, and up to overnight then you would have to reheat the oil to 400°F., add the chicken pieces and cook until completely crisp for about 5 minutes.

provenance.page_title: The Best Buttermilk-Brined Southern Fried Chicken Recipe
provenance.section_title: The Best Buttermilk-Brined Southern Fried Chicken Recipe
provenance.paragraph_text: When ready to serve, reheat the oil to 400°F.

provenance.page_title: The Best Buttermilk-Brined Southern Fried Chicken Recipe
provenance.section_title: The Best Buttermilk-Brined Southern Fried Chicken Recipe
provenance.paragraph_text: Add the chicken pieces and cook, flipping them once halfway through cooking, until completely crisp, about 5 minutes.

provenance.paragraph_text: Place the plate of cooked chicken in the refrigerator for at least 1 hour, and up to overnight.

conversation.utterance: is it safe to use the oil your used in the beginning as you do in the last step

You don't have to throw out used oil. Often you can reuse it many, many times! but there's no hard and fast rule for how many time you can reuse that oil. Distrust any source that gives a firm answer on the number times you can reuse oil. It's easy to tell when you'll need to replace your oil.

conversation.utterance: is the oil safe since you cooked raw chicken in it to begin with

I'm not sure I have an answer to your question. However, as a general rule  the more oil breaks down, the less hydrophobic it becomes. At first, this can actually be an advantage. Less hydrophobic molecules in your oil means that it can come into closer contact with foods, allowing them to fry just a bit more efficiently. However,   as this breakdown continues, your oil becomes less and less hydrophobic, and eventually it'll start entering your food too rapidly, causing it to turn greasy and ruining its crispness. At this point you would have to change it

provenance.page_title: How Many Times Can I Re-Use Fry Oil? | Ask the Food Lab
provenance.section_title: What About Oil Freshness?
provenance.paragraph_text: The more oil breaks down, the less hydrophobic it becomes. At first, this can actually be an advantage. Less hydrophobic molecules in your oil means that it can come into closer contact with foods, allowing them to fry just a bit more efficiently. This is where the wisdom of those tempura chefs comes in—adding a bit of degraded, old fry oil to the new batch will improve it.

provenance.page_title: How Many Times Can I Re-Use Fry Oil? | Ask the Food Lab
provenance.section_title: What About Oil Freshness?
provenance.paragraph_text: Eventually, as this breakdown continues, your oil becomes less and less hydrophobic, and eventually it'll start entering your food too rapidly, causing it to turn greasy and ruining its crispness.
